# Grouped bar graphs {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-tip appearance='simple' icon=false} ***This graph is largely complete and just needs final proof reading.*** ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ## Graph info ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #007bff;"} **Should I use this graph?** :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](grp_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #007bff;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #fa7b3c;"} **✅ a categorical variable** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #fa7b3c;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** ::: :::: ## Description `geom_col()` allows us to display 'grouped' numerical values across levels (or groups) of a categorical variable. Grouped bar graphs assume the statistical measure (i.e., the value that the length of the bars will be derived from) is contained in a variable and mapped to the `x` or `y` aesthetic. ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Remove the missing values and reduce the `palmerpenguins::penguins` dataset to only `body_mass_g` and `island`, then group the data by `island` and calculate the mean `body_mass_g` (as `avg_body_mass_g`). ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} peng_grp_col <- palmerpenguins::penguins |> dplyr::select(body_mass_g, island) |> tidyr::drop_na() |> dplyr::group_by(island) |> dplyr::summarise( avg_body_mass_g = mean(body_mass_g) ) |> dplyr::ungroup() glimpse(peng_grp_col) #> Rows: 3 #> Columns: 2 #> $ island Biscoe, Dream, Torgersen #> $ avg_body_mass_g 4716.018, 3712.903, 3706.373 ``` ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` Map `island` to the `x` and `avg_body_mass_g` to the `y` Map `island` to `fill` *inside* the `aes()` of `geom_col()` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_grp_col <- labs( title = "Average Penguin Mass", subtitle = "What's the average mass of penguins per Island?", x = "Island", y = "Average penguin body mass (g)") ggp2_grp_col <- ggplot(data = peng_grp_col, aes(x = island, y = avg_body_mass_g)) + geom_col(aes(fill = island), show.legend = FALSE) ggp2_grp_col + labs_grp_col ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](grp_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/create_graph_grp_col-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: ::::
